The Nature of Humanity

A dimly lit room; three friends in deep thought.  
Raskolnikov looks troubled.  
Razumihin: “Are you both joking?”  

Raskolnikov: “I’m serious…”  
Porfiry: “Making fun of one another?”  

Raskolnikov: “A law exists, unseen…”  
Razumihin: “What’s original in all this?”  

---  

A close-up on Raskolnikov's pale face.  
His expression is mournful, lost in thought.  
Porfiry: “Sarcasm feels strange next to you.”  

Razumihin: “We’ve heard this before, right?”  
Raskolnikov: “One in a million is born free.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The text discusses the rarity of individuals with true independence and genius among the vast majority of humanity, suggesting that a natural law governs this phenomenon.
